questionsData.title: An alkali has a sour taste.
Car battery contains citric acid.
Claws are on the bird's mouth.
Banana has a curved shape.
A tractor is a machine used by a farmer.
Buying food means grazing.
On rough surfaces, the angles of incidence and reflection are the same.
A drought is a shortage of water.
The earth moves and shakes during drought.
Painkiller is used to get rid of headaches.
Plantation is a land planted with trees.
Vaccines nowadays are commonplace.
"To be willing" means "to be ready".
The strength of the earthquake is measured on the Richter scale.
"Annum" means "yearly".
A suffix is added to the end of the word.
Things you use in cooking are ingredients.
Apples, oranges and pears are vegetables.
The moon gets its light from the sun.
The front part of the ship is called a mast.
The text is mainly talking about………………….
questionsData.article: Tears usually show how you feel. When you're unhappy, tears roll down on your cheeks. Sometime tears drop from your eyes when you are happy, or if you laugh very hard. But tears have amoreimportant job than showing how you feel. All day long your eyes sit in a bath of tears. These tearskeep your eyes clean and healthy. They wash away dirt and germs and other things that get into your eyes. Your eyes also need tears to keep them wet. Your eyes must be wet so that they can move smoothly. If they didn’t, move smoothly, you'd have to turn your head to look at things that weren’t right in front of you. If you didn’t have tears, your eyes couldn't move and soon you would be blind. Under each eyelid are tiny sacs called tear glands. That's where cears are made. Generally your eyes can’t do without tears. All day long tears wash your eyes to keep them.

questionsData.title: There was ….. interesting film on TV last night.
questionsData.explain_answer:
"There was an interesting film on TV last night."

In this sentence, "an" is used as an indefinite article before the singular, countable noun "film".

"Interesting" is an adjective that describes the noun "film".
